title: Stunt flyer Glenn Collins remains in hospital after Avalon Airshow crash
text:
A pilot who crashed during a demonstration flight at Avalon International Airshow in Victoria is in a serious but stable condition in hospital, his team have said in a statement.

The aircraft, piloted by Glenn Collins from Paul Bennet's Airshows team, lost control while performing a manoeuvre and crashed into the tarmac just after 5pm.﻿

Vision from the scene shows the aircraft slamming into the ground.

READ MORE: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese calls federal election for May 3

Vision from the scene appears to show one of four aircrafts plummeting to the ground during an aerobatics performance. (Facebook)

Collins suffered serious upper and lower body injuries and has been taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition.

The aerobatics team Paul Bennet Airshows confirmed last night that one of their long-time pilots was involved in the crash.

"The pilot is in a serious but stable condition and has been transferred to hospital for treatment," the team said in a statement.

"Our thoughts are with his family and we are grateful for the emergency services who responded quickly."

The aircraft, piloted by Glenn Collins from Paul Bennet's Airshows team, lost control while performing a manoeuvre and crashed into the tarmac just after 5pm.﻿ (Paul Bennets Airshows)

"Our team and families appreciate the well-wishes and support."

Later they said, "The Bennet family and the Paul Bennet Airshows team are thinking of Glenn Collins, who remains in hospital, and his family at this time."

"We would like to acknowledge the extraordinary level of support from medical staff as well as messages of support received from here and around the world."

Emergency services are on scene at the International Air Show, where a small plane has crashed on the tarmac.. (Facebook)

Gasps could be heard from the crowd of thousands as the plane hit the ground.

"He had broken off from the other three, and on the second loop, he just nose-dived," witness Jess Wright told Weekend Today.

"We all just stood up, and it was just silent."

"There was a little bit of a gasp, then silence."

After the crash, the rest of the evening's program was cancelled as emergency services rushed to the pilot's aid.

Overnight, a message on the airshow's website confirmed that the "event will recommence, gates open 8am Saturday".

Collins has more than 2700 hours of flying experience and has previously won aerobatics competitions throughout his career, according to a biography on the Paul Bennet Airshows ﻿website.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) has commenced an investigation﻿ and is appealing for any witnesses with video footage to make contact via its witness form

"The ATSB is deploying a team of transport safety investigators from its Canberra office, specialising in aircraft operations and maintenance," a spokesperson said.

"Investigators will conduct a range of evidence-gathering activities, including site and wreckage examination, and recovery of any aircraft components for further examination at the ATSB's technical facilities in Canberra.

"Investigators will also seek to interview any involved parties, and collect relevant recorded information including available flight tracking data, as well as pilot and aircraft maintenance records, and weather information."

The six-day event is the largest international airshow and aerospace and defence exposition in the Southern Hemisphere﻿.

title: 'You don't matter': Teens forced to wait up to 127 days for mental health support
text:
Australian teenagers ﻿are waiting months on average for critical mental health support and experts agree it's too long.

New research has shown that lengthy wait times are associated with ﻿increased psychological distress and poor coping behaviours, putting young Aussies at greater risk while they wait for help.

Research from The University of New South Wales, Black Dog Institute, and Flinders University﻿ found that teens wait an average of 99 days for mental health support across all treatment providers.

LIVE UPDATES: Prime Minister reveals election date

Milly Rose Bannister, founder of youth mental health charity ALLKND, is unsurprised by new research around treatment wait times. (Graphic: Polly Hanning)

Milly Rose Bannister, founder of youth mental health charity ALLKND , is devastated but unsurprised by the data.

"For a young person to reach the point of asking for help takes a lot of courage and then being told to wait three or four months can feel like being told you don't matter," she told 9news.com.au.

"In a world where so many teens already feel unseen, unheard, or overwhelmed, that wait time can be the tipping point."

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

The study ﻿was based on based on a survey of 375 Australians aged between 13 and 17.

It found that teen participants who initiated care with psychiatrists waited an average of 127.5 days, the longest wait time of any provider.

Those seeking support from psychologists waited an average of 100.1 days, while the average wait time for paediatricians was 121.9 days, and the wait for national youth mental health foundation Headspace was 107.6 days.

Long wait times can be attributed, in part, to a shortage of key providers like psychiatrists and higher demand for mental health support among young people. ﻿

"We hear stories from young people who've waited months for a first appointment, been turned away, or given referrals to services they can't afford or even get to," Bannister said.

"Some say they've just stopped trying [...] because the system feels impossible to navigate, especially when you're already struggling."

Most teen participants did not receive support from healthcare providers during that wait time and reported that their mental health worsened while waiting.

Longer wait times were associated with ﻿increased psychological distress, with more than two-thirds of participants reporting that feelings of sadness worsened while waiting.

Many also ﻿reported engaging in unhealthy coping behaviours while waiting for care.

More than 92 per cent of participants reported engaging in maladaptive coping behaviours like spending more time alone, sleeping, or scrolling social media.

A further 75 per cent reported engaging in risky behaviours such as ﻿self-harming, skipping school, drinking alcohol, vaping and smoking.

Long wait times can also lead to teens not attending treatment when the time finally comes.

More than half of the 14.7 per cent of participants ﻿who reported that they were likely to attend their first treatment session said it was because "the wait time was too long".

There were some positives, like the fact that almost nine in 10 participants employed help-seeking﻿ behaviours while waiting for care, such as looking up mental health information online.

But overall ﻿the research highlighted the urgent need for systemic reform in the delivery of youth mental health services according to Professor Bridianne O'Dea, one of the lead researchers.

"We are now in the midst of a crisis where the demand for youth mental health care has increased rapidly in the past two decades," she said, via Scimex .

"The first line of treatment is psychological therapy. There is a huge demand for it and we do not have the number of clinicians required to meet that demand."

Young people who took part in the study called for better communication and ﻿regular check-ins from service providers to help address the burden of waiting for care.

O'Dea called for the introduction of evidence-based, government-backed national wait time benchmarks to help reduce how long Australian teens wait for critical support.

"Everyone needs someone safe to talk to," Bannister said. (Instagram/@millyrosebannister)

"We don't accept delayed response times for physical injuries, so why do we still tolerate it for mental health?" Bannister said.

Through ALLKND, she advocates for early intervention and funding towards ﻿youth-specific mental health services and community-based, integrated care including peer workers, school programs, and youth-led initiatives.

"Everyone needs someone safe to talk to. If we can lighten the load at the crisis end, the whole system becomes more sustainable," she said.

While the 2025-26 federal budget released this week promised to inject billions into Australia's healthcare system, Black Dog Institute reported that the mental health sector remains critically underfunded.

The budget included an ﻿$8.4 billion investment over four years to boost bulk billing for GP appointments, which are usually the first port of call for young people seeking mental health treatment.

More than $784 million will go towards capping PBS medication costs over the next four years, including mental health medications.

A further $46 million will go towards delivering free digital mental health tools over four years, which young Australians are already looking to for support during wait times.

WATCH: Chris Kohler's two-minute guide to the 2025 federal budget﻿

Bannister says that while the figures sound promising, the current budget measures will have a limited impact on the youth mental health crisis.

"This is a national emergency and we cannot solve it with small-scale, long-term gestures," she said.

Without long-term investment into accessible services, youth mental health literacy programs, and culturally safe care for marginalised youth, Bannister fears young Australians struggling with mental health will continue to fall through the cracks.

﻿"Mental health support needs to meet young people where they are, not ask them to climb mountains to access it."

Readers seeking support can contact Lifeline on 13 11 14 or beyond blue on 1300 22 4636. Under-25s can contact Kids Helpline on 1800 55 1800.

title: Two out of three experts think RBA will keep interest rates on hold
text:
M﻿ortgage holders hoping for further relief on interest rates when the Reserve Bank of Australia meets next week will be disappointed, according to new research.

The board meeting starting next Monday will be the first since the RBA made its long-anticipated cut last month, bringing the cash rate down to 4.10 per cent.

﻿Now a Finder survey of 34 economists has found two out of three think the central bank will keep the cash rate on hold when the RBA announces its decision on Tuesday afternoon (AEDT).

LIVE UPDATES: PM calls election for May 3

The RBA are unlikely to deliver further relief on interest rates next week, a survey of experts has found. (9News)

It's a big shift in sentiment from hopes last month's cut would kick off consecutive cash rate reductions through this year.﻿

Finder head of consumer research Graham Cooks said it looked like mortgage holders will have to hold out until May for the next cut.

"The February cut signalled a turning point for many cash-strapped borrowers – they hoped a couple more would be coming thick and fast," he said.

"New inflation figures show headline inflation is within target range, so while we're unlikely to see a second rate cut in April, we're anticipating further relief from May onwards." ﻿

Despite a thumping belief the RBA will keep interest rates on hold, six of the 34 experts believe there is a case for slashing them.

One of them was Leanne Pilkington from Laing+Simmons who thinks a cut next month would be shrewd in light of recent jobs numbers.﻿

Last week's data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained flat at 4.1 per cent.

"As well as sustained cost of living pressure and moderating inflation, the unexpected hit to employment figures has widened the window of opportunity for the RBA to cut rates, which it is expected to do in coming months anyway. It might be prudent to act now," Pilkington said.

The survey was carried out before today's announcement by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese an election would be held on May 3, a factor alluded to by one expert.

Australia's fastest-selling homes: top suburbs revealed View Gallery

"Another rate cut coming soon but not just yet—it's not urgent, and the bank will want to keep a low profile during the election campaign," said Geoffrey Kingston, of the Macquarie University Business School in Sydney.

Looking ahead, two in three experts surveyed forecast two or three more cuts this year.

A thumping 93 per cent also thought lenders would continue to pass on the next cut to the cash rate in full.﻿

title: Woman undergoes heart transplant within two weeks of brain surgery
text:
As Richelle Murray swims laps in her local pool, she can breathe more easily than she has for a long time.

"I feel free. I love it, life is good," she said.

The 63-year-old spent decades living with a rare congenital heart disease before she received a heart transplant in October 2023.

It came just two weeks after she had brain surgery after suffering a stroke.

"At the time, you aren't looking at the trauma. You are just trying to move on to the next bit," Richelle said.

" It isn't until later that you go, 'Oh, wow! That was a lot to cope with.' "

After a challenging recovery, Richelle has now made it past the critical first 12 months post-transplant and is embracing life in her community at Taree on the New South Wales Mid North Coast.

"I can take my grandkids for a swim … spending time with my family, and interacting and enjoying life. What a blessing," she said.

"It also makes you stop for that moment and think about where your heart came from … I'm grateful."

Richelle says she loves feeling well enough to spend active time with her grandchildren. (Supplied: Richelle Murray )

Two of Richelle's three sons have the same genetic heart disease, which she was not diagnosed with until after starting her family.

The experience has inspired her to become an advocate for organ donation.

"I wouldn't be here if there wasn't an organ donor," Richelle said.

" I am living proof of the impact organ donors can have. "

Long road to heart transplant

Richelle has a genetic defect on the lamin a/c gene, which causes cardiomyopathy and problems with the heart's electrical conduction system.

Richelle Murray at a formal event, before having her heart transplant. (Supplied: Richelle Murray)

She noticed early symptoms, including shortness of breath in her 20s and her condition gradually worsened.

'While resting, my heartbeat would race, stall, and skip in unsettling waves, causing persistent jitters," Richelle said.

" You don't understand what it's like for other people … until you go and do something, say a walk up a hill, and everyone is at the top of the hill, and you are only 10 per cent of the way up. "

Richelle in hospital after her transplant in October 2023, with her sons Bill Murray (left) and Nic Murray. (Supplied: Richelle Murray)

By the age of 60, Richelle had undergone multiple advanced treatments, including the installation of four pacemakers and cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) — a device used to counter heart failure.

But a critical moment came when her CRT device delivered a lifesaving defibrillation, saving her life but causing her to collapse.

A fresh series of health evaluations followed, and at 61, Richelle qualified for the heart transplant waiting list.

Just weeks later, she had a major stroke and underwent emergency brain surgery.

"By sheer chance, I was in Sydney to do a test at the hospital … and I had the stroke in the hotel," she said.

'If it had happened when I was home at Taree, I might not be here chatting today."

Remarkably, less than two weeks after her brain surgery, Richelle received the life-altering phone call that a heart was available, and she needed to urgently travel back to Sydney for her transplant.

From esky to 'heart in a box'

Richelle's surgeon at Sydney's St Vincent's Hospital, Arjun Iyer, said heart transplant success rates were high.

Heart transplant surgeon Arjun Iyer says technology has helped extend donor heart viability. (Supplied: Arjun Iyer)

"These days, we [St Vincent's] end up doing between 60 to 70 heart transplants a year," he said.

"The risk of death is generally quoted at 10 per cent within the first 12 months after a transplant … so 90 per cent of people are alive after 12 months."

Dr Iyer said technological advancements, including 'heart-in-a-box' perfusion systems, had extended donor heart viability and allowed those needing a transplant more time to get to the hospital, particularly from regional and rural areas.

"The most common way of preserving the hearts used to be in an esky with some ice," he said.

"We still use the cold storage old school way of preserving hearts … but as we are starting to use donors who are further away … we needed to develop further technology to try and preserve these hearts for a longer period of time.

"Sometimes the heart is in a beating state, you have it oxygenated in the machine."

St Vincent's Hospital Sydney is a busy Australian heart transplant centre. (ABC News: Patrick Thomas)

The machines have also paved the way for "donation after circulatory death" (DCD) donors, as opposed to only brain dead donors.

"It's increased our heart transplant numbers by about 30 per cent," Dr Iyer said.

Calls for more organ donors

There is a strong need for more organ donors in Australia, with a 5 per cent decrease in the total number of transplant recipients last year.

Richelle now takes immunosuppressant medications and is closely monitored, but feels strong. (ABC News: Emma Siossian)

Juliana Celcer, Director of Nursing at DonateLife NSW, said one organ donor could save the lives of up to seven people, and help many more through organ and tissue donation.

She said it was essential people discussed their wishes with their families.

title: Curry has become symbolic of Indian cuisine, but it's more complicated
text:
When many of us think of Indian food, we think of curry.

ABC Every Bite Every Bite tells a story – the stories behind the food we love to eat.

That saucy and aromatic blend of spices, meat, and vegetables, often slow-cooked and served with rice and traditional naan bread or roti.

But, surprisingly, the word curry doesn't originate from India.

Out of all the major pre-colonial languages spoken in India, none of them contain the word curry.

So, how did the dish become the poster child of authentic Indian cuisine?

Curry's origin story

Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama reached Calicut on the Malabar Coast in 1498.

It was the beginning of the European and British presence in India that would eventually change the subcontinent in multiple ways, including shaping how we view Indian cuisine today.

"When you really dig deep, nobody really knows where [the word] curry comes from," Lizzie Collingham, a researcher and author, tells ABC Radio National's Every Bite.

Melbourne chef Helly Raichura cooks traditional regional Indian food. (ABC Radio National: Damien Peck )

Dr Collingham says the arrival of the Portuguese is the earliest record of the word curry being applied to Indian dishes.

With the arrival of European and British settlers in India, mainly around Goa and Cochin (now Kochi), the word curry became a way to refer to what Indian people were eating.

"Curry was a word the Portuguese used and then when the British picked it up … That's what they called any dish that an Indian [person] ate," Dr Collingham says.

But it wasn't what Indian people called their food.

The colonisation of India's cuisine

Over time Indian dishes, like many other traditional cuisines around the world, have evolved through colonisation and migration.

Many of the ingredients thought of as staples of Indian food, including curry, were historically introduced to the subcontinent, often by a colonial presence or changes within society.

Lizzie Collingham says the history of the word "curry" is complicated. (Penguin Books: Terry Roopnaraine)

For example, when the Portuguese arrived in Goa, India, they found that the Brahmins (priests who belonged to the highest Hindu hereditary class) didn't eat onion and garlic for spiritual reasons.

"Brahmins wouldn't have used onion and garlic because they were considered rather heating and dangerous foods for spiritual people," Dr Collingham says.

"But the ruling classes would eat quite a lot of it, and meat, and put a lot of spices in."

And chillies? They didn't exist in India until the Portuguese settlers brought them to Goa and Cochin from the Americas.

In fact, it was black and long pepper that were used by Indian people during that period to add heat to their food.

The exchange of spices and regional ingredients was part of the reason why the Portuguese had a presence in India, Dr Collingham explains.

An ingredient synonymous with Indian food, chillies were actually introduced by European settlers from the Americas. (Supplied: Hardie Grant Publishing)

"Cardamoms grow in the hills in what's now Kerala above Cochin. And you've got spices being brought in like nutmeg and cloves … So, all those spices would have been plentifully used in Indian food in that period," she says.

And so in Goa, during this time, dishes that we now associate with the term "curry" began to emerge.

The British touch

Over a long period, the British presence in India increased. Eventually, it transitioned into political and military dominance over a large part of the country.

Stream your favourite shows on the free ABC listen app Photo shows Image of Dr Karl on a pink background and Listen app logo Dr Karl knows the best app for free podcasts, radio, music, news and audiobooks … and you don't need to be a scientist to find it!

The British had Indian cooks working for them, and these workers would adapt their food to suit their customers.

"It was too spicy and too difficult for the English to digest … So they adapted their dishes to meet British tastes," Dr Collingham says.

The British enjoyed these dishes and tried to replicate them back in Britain, but they found being authentic to the process was too labour-intensive.

Curry is symbolic of Indian food, but its affiliation is complicated for many. (ABC News: David Sier)

"They [the British] have this awful way of whatever they touch, they tend to homogenise," she says.

And soon curry powder came to be. It was an entirely British invention.

" So they fry some onions, they dump in some curry powder, they dump in some meat and water, and they stew it … And that's what the British call curry. "

True to home

Authentic Indian cuisine is based on seasonal produce specific to the regions. And it's traditionally reflective of the classes Indian people belong to.

Chef Helly Raichura, who owns the Melbourne Indian restaurant, Enter via Laundry, says adapting to changing seasonal and historical environments is a feature of Indian cuisine.

Spices were a hot trade item for many years. (ABC: Damien Peck)

"Evolution is the only constant in Indian food because it has changed so much," she says.

Ms Raichura avoids cooking stereotypical Indian cuisine in her restaurant.

Instead, she relies on the foundations of what was passed down through her family to cook what she believes is an authentic Indian regional menu.

"They [her ancestors] were very much connected to the land. They were very much connected to where they were and taking and using things that were seasonal for them," she says.

Chef Helly Raichura says using in-season ingredients is key. (ABC: Damien Peck )

When Ms Raichura arrived in Australia, she was surprised to see seasonal produce wasn't prioritised in the same way it is in India.

"It was very shocking to me to see very bad quality tomatoes that you can still buy in winter … I was like, just don't sell it," she says.

Ms Raichura believes India's strong relationship with seasonal food enhances the eating experience.

"There are rituals and recipes at specific times of the year that are cherished," she says.

"You're not getting strawberries in winter, you're waiting for it. There's an anticipation."

The intersection of curry and identity

We've often heard Italians baulk at the Westernised state of Italian cuisine — particularly pizza.

And the same thing can be said for many traditional cuisines around the world including Japanese, Thai and Mexican.

So it's little wonder that many Indians have struggled with associating curry as a symbol of authentic Indian cuisine.

Helly Richura says Indian food is constantly evolving. (ABC Radio National: Damien Peck )

"I think there are a lot of layers to what Indian food is and layers of history and then when you put it down to just the C word [curry] … you know?" Ms Raichura says.

"For the longest time ever, no self-respecting Indian said, ‘I'm going to have a curry tonight' … That wasn't in the vocabulary," Dr Collingham says.

Understanding the history of their cuisine, and how it shapes their identity today is sometimes a complex task for Indians, Canadian author Naben Ruthnum adds.

"I'm a postcolonial mess of a person over here who's scraped together an identity that has very little to do with my country of origin."

And today, for many Indians all over the world, curry has taken on a different meaning, despite its ambiguous and colonial origins.

"To me, it's come to sort of represent a blend of identities," Ruthnum says.

Despite being a colonial invention, some Indians have learned to embrace the word curry and reclaim the dish as symbolic of their complex history, he explains.

"It's come to represent a food that I really like, and it's come to represent all the things that I didn't really understand about history and myself."

title: Sewage running through North Queensland properties as rain continues
text:
Raw sewage is running through properties in Australia's largest northern city after months of record-breaking rain.

More than two metres of rain has fallen in Townsville since January, with the city on track to beat its 25-year annual rainfall record of 2,400 millimetres within days.

The near-unprecedented rain has put extreme pressure on sewerage infrastructure.

Residents say they are living in intolerable conditions, with reports of sewage flowing back through pipes and onto properties.

Health concerns

Andrew and Sue Koning this week again woke up to human waste and sodden toilet paper bubbling from a drain on their driveway.

Andrew Konings says his driveway flooded with sewage during heavy rain this week. (Supplied: Andrew Konings)

"We've been having a shit time, literally," he said.

" Every time we get a pretty decent mob of rain, we get sewerage flooding out through our property. "

The Konings have had to hose sewage away to get to their cars numerous times since heavy rain started in the city on January 31.

"If you don't get onto it straight away, it just stinks," he said.

Mr Koning said the local council has told him that incessant rain has overwhelmed the city's sewerage system, and little could be done until rain eases.

Camp amenities

The Townsville suburb of Wulguru has had long-running issues with the sewerage system, but it's been especially bad this wet season.

Wulguru resident and mother-of-four Brittany Giudes said the situation was intolerable.

Brittany Giudes says drastic remedial work had to be undertaken on her bathroom. (ABC North Qld: Cameron Simmons)

"We've just had sewage coming up every drain possible in our house," she said.

" Raw, human sewage waste from the laundry to the bathroom. "

A back-flow valve installed by the council has now prevented sewage erupting through pipes on the property, but the family can only use a camp shower and toilet until the situation is resolved.

"We need a permanent solution," Ms Giudes said.

A few blocks away, 85-year-old Betty Cutts has to use a modified bucket for a toilet and can no longer wash her clothes or use a shower.

"I can smell it from the shower, from the toilet, from the sink in the laundry," she said.

"It makes me sick."

Betty Cutts can no longer wash her clothes or use her toilet or shower. (ABC North Qld: Cameron Simmons)

System overwhelmed

Townsville City Council general manager for water services, Travis Richards, said the sewerage system had been overwhelmed with rainfall and stormwater during a record wet season.

He estimated there had been upwards of 600 complaints about the system this year but stressed the vast majority of homes in Townsville were fine.

Mr Richards said low-lying and older areas were under pressure.

"There's a significant amount of more water to move around, and that uses up capacity in the system, and in certain areas, people can't use their toilet or their shower because there's literally no room left," he said.

Mr Richards said the council was working with residents to clean up and disinfect areas, and improvements had been made in Wulguru.

"We do have small pockets still affected and we are working on effective infrastructure solutions for them," he said.

" There's no silver bullet. "

Longing for clear skies

Andrew and Sue Konings said the impacts of this year's rain had been the worst they had seen.

"It's not just another wet season — my wife and I have never seen it this bad," Mr Konings said.

"I just hope it can be sorted out so we can wake up in the morning and I'm not spending half an hour to get rid of the sewage and the smell.

title: Kasatkina, world number 12, switches allegiances to represent Australia
text:
Russian-born tennis star Daria Kasatkina is switching allegiances to Australia after her application for permanent residency was accepted by the government.

The world number 12 has been playing on the tour as a neutral athlete after Russian and Belarusian players were banned from competing under their own flags following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

In an Instagram post, Kasatkina expressed her joy in gaining permanent residency in Australia.

"I am delighted to let you all know that my application for permanent residency has been accepted by the Australian government.

"Australia is a place I love, is incredibly welcoming and a place where I feel totally at home.

"I love being in Melbourne and look forward to making my home there.

"As part of this, I am proud to announce that I will be representing my new homeland Australia, in my professional tennis career from this point onwards."

The 27-year-old rose as high as number eight in the world and has won eight WTA titles — her best grand slam result coming at the French Open where she reached the semi-finals in 2022.

AAP

title: Assisted dying rules exclude people with dementia. Will it change?
text:
Sue Starr would rather end her life than spend years battling dementia.

The former home care worker has even put that on record, asking for access to Voluntary Assisted Dying (VAD) should she be diagnosed.

But it would currently be illegal for anyone to make good on that request.

Adults with a terminal illness can apply for medicine to end their lives in all Australian states, with the Australian Capital Territory to start in November.

But applicants must meet strict criteria, including having "decision-making capacity" and their illness is likely to cause death within six to 12 months.

This effectively bars access to anyone with dementia.

Ms Starr, who spent 12 years working at Home Care in the West Australian seaside town of Esperance and currently runs the local chapter of Death Cafe, wants that to change.

Although she is currently healthy, she is adamant that if diagnosed with dementia, she "would rather go quickly".

" If I can't make my decisions anymore for myself, and if I can't wash and clean myself and feed myself under my own direction, then I want to access Voluntary Assisted Dying. "

Ms Starr has requested access to VAD if she has dementia and is deteriorating. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

Ms Starr has used an Advanced Health Directive, a legal document setting out a person's healthcare wishes for when they can no longer make them, to request access to VAD after two years of living with dementia.

She knows it would currently be illegal for any healthcare professional to follow through on this request, but wanted it recorded anyway.

"My first port of call was to say to my doctor … 'Can you just put it in your record that if I'm diagnosed with dementia, I want to access Voluntary Assisted Dying?'," she said.

"And he said, 'I can't do that because it's not legal'.

" And I said, 'I realise that but in the future it may be'. "

Dementia Australia said the illness was on track to become the country's leading cause of death and currently affects an estimated 433,300 Australians.

Ms Starr is among those urging state governments to at least discuss the possibility of broadening VAD laws to include dementia in the future.

But recent reviews of WA and Victoria's laws barely touched on the subject.

Ms Starr hopes eligibility laws for VAD will expand in the future. (ABC Esperance: Emily Smith)

Dementia debate

Dying with Dignity WA president Steve Walker has long urged the state government to consider expanding VAD laws to people with dementia through an Advanced Health Directive.

He was disappointed the idea was not considered during a statutory review of WA's laws last year, particularly as other countries now allow it.

"The government in effect, they shutdown any discussion on this," he said.

WA Health Minister Meredith Hammat said the review was never about changing the scope of current laws, only assessing whether they were working as intended.

She said it was vital people accessing VAD could provide informed consent throughout the entire process.

Australian Medical Association's ethics and medico legal committee chair Kerrie Aust is a big believer in broader public debate about VAD.

Canberra GP Dr Kerrie Aust does not support expanding VAD laws for people with dementia. (Supplied: Ainsley Fisher)

But she did not currently support opening access to those with dementia.

"My personal view is that we don't have sufficient processes in place to have dementia included as part of an Advanced Care Directive," she said.

"Where my hesitation comes in is because you often don't know what your future self would want.

"Dementia is a very broad spectrum, and I think an assumption that all people with dementia are suffering and unhappy is not the experience of the majority of our geriatricians."

She said it was certainly worth monitoring the success of models used overseas and evaluating their data to see the potential risks and benefits in the future.

More than law change required

South Australia-based wills and estates lawyer Nikki Owen said a person who requests VAD through an Advanced Health Directive today would be very unlikely to ever access it, even if laws around dementia were to change.

Nikki Owen says strict rules limit access to VAD for people with dementia in countries where it is legal. (Supplied: Mellor Olsson Lawyers)

Across the handful of countries where people with dementia can access VAD, strict parameters are in place.

In Canada's Quebec, for example, the request to access VAD must be formalised after being diagnosed with Alzheimer's but before losing the ability to make informed decisions.

Ms Owen believed if any Australian states were to permit VAD for people with dementia in the future, it would be with similarly strict conditions and the Advanced Health Directive would need to be formulated after the law came in.

But she said she had come across those determined to include it.

"I've come across one or two and I've explained to them that it's not legally binding," she said.

"[But] there's no harm in it.

"As long as you just expressed the wish and you say in there that you understand it at the moment, it's not something that you can bind anybody to do."

Ms Starr believes there was value in having her views formalised.

title: Light rail survey to favour neighbouring residents above others
text:
Residents in one of Australia's fastest growing cities will be able to have their say on a controversial light rail project for the second time in three years.

But this time not everyone's opinions will be viewed equally.

The light rail Stage 3 is currently under construction to Burleigh Heads. (ABC News)

Locals who live near Stage 4 of the Gold Coast's light rail project will have their views prioritised, according to Deputy Premier Jarrod Bleijie.

He said it was because the project was "forced upon the people of the southern end of the Gold Coast without proper community consultation".

Jarrod Bleijie said he was listening to what southern Gold Coasters want. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

A consultation by the previous state government found more than 60 per cent of residents and businesses supported the final stage of the project, which is set to run 13 kilometres from Burleigh Heads to Coolangatta.

That independent research surveyed over 1,000 businesses and residents over 220 hours.

Palm Beach brewer John Graham supports the project, but resides in an area home to vocal opposition to the project.

He said Palm Beach had gentrified in the 24 years he had lived there, with cranes and high-rises popping up along the once sleepy beachside strip.

John Graham hoped the light rail would free up Palm Beach car spots. (ABC Gold Coast: Julia Andre)

He said the light rail line would benefit the suburb by taking cars off the road and allowing people to more easily access public transport.

However, Palm Beach cafe owner Todd Hiscock does not want rail to run along the beachfront like the existing line from Surfers Paradise to Broadbeach.

Todd Hiscock does not want to see the fourth stage of the light rail go ahead. (ABC Gold Coast: Julia Andre)

"[I'm] all for public infrastructure, but infrastructure that actually improves the situation, not makes it worse," Mr Hiscock said.

He said he preferred more bus lanes, which had previously been investigated in government reports and were found to be slower, have a shorter life span, and have a "similar range of cost".

'Describe a great public transport system'

What the light rail might look like over Currumbin Creek on the Gold Coast. (Supplied: Queensland government)

In the latest surveys for the project, residents were asked to enter their address, but they do not have to provide their name or identifiable information.

It appears that multiple submissions can be made from a single address.

The four questions asked in the latest light rail survey: How would you describe a great public transport system for your local area?

What are your concerns on the current proposal for light rail expansion in the southern Gold Coast?

Do you feel that you were properly consulted in the prior process?

In your opinion, what key features or services are important to consider for developing a great public transport system in your local area? Residents are also asked to rank whether affordability, accessibility, frequency, or proximity is most important when considering public transport options.

Mr Bleijie said southern Gold Coast residents' submissions would be prioritised over others and that he was open to all modes of transport.

"Those residents in the southern Gold Coast will be obviously taken into more consideration because that's who we have committed this promise to," he said.

The LNP government promised to review the project ahead of last year's state election.

"We promised we'd listen to them and take their feedback on board. We all know the Labor party already had made up their mind [on the project]," Mr Bleijie said.

Support for reviews

Real estate developer Steven Harrison, who leads the business advisory that advocates for the project, said he welcomed the new consultation process.

But he said he was concerned about discussion again about different transport modes, adding that buses were not as efficient as the light rail which has been used by about 92 million passengers since the Gold Coast line opened.

The light rail in Nerang on the Gold Coast. (ABC News: Richard Johnson)

"We've got a small footprint along that coastal route, we need to be more efficient with how we move people," Mr Harrison said.

"I hope the current government hasn't decided against light rail to the airport."

Opposition leader Steven Miles said the LNP had never supported Stage 4. (ABC News: Kenji Sato)

Queensland state opposition leader Steven Miles said local LNP state MPs in the area had "consistently undermined" the project.

"They've been looking for ways to stop it," he said.

'Got to explain truthfully'

Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate said the current survey method prioritising the views of residents on the southern end of the Gold Coast was "not normal".

"Perhaps it's contentious politically for them [the government]," he said.

Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate has long advocated to transform the city's public transport system. (ABC Gold Coast: Dominic Cansdale)

" There's got to be balance. You've got to explain truthfully 'yeah, there's a lot of pain but there's a lot of gain'. "

He said southern Gold Coast suburbs face increasing congestion and the light rail was his solution to the issue as residents face the threat of gridlock within the next few years.

He said if campaigns by neighbouring residents resulted in the rail line being scrapped "that's the consequence that you're going to have to live with".

title: Analysts warn reliance on Beetaloo gas over renewables a risky strategy
text:
The Northern Territory government is relying on gas as the key to bringing down local power prices, but energy analysts say it's risky to put all the eggs in the gas basket.

On Thursday, the NT Country Liberal Party (CLP) government officially scrapped its target of 50 per cent renewables by 2030.

Renewables Minister Gerard Maley said he wanted a mix of energy sources.

"We've either got gas or renewables, and renewables has failed dismally," he said.

" We've got gas — that's what we've got to use and that's what we'll be relying on. "

Gerard Maley says renewable energy is expensive. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

The Northern Territory has lagged behind every Australian jurisdiction in the switch to renewables, behind Western Australia and Queensland, according to Climate Council data.

Gas policy has devil in the detail Photo shows Liquified natural gas plant and LNG ship on Curtis Island, Queensland Experts say the time to establish a gas reservation policy has passed, and plans to bring more gas online are years away and will fail to provide immediate relief to power prices.

Tasmania achieved 100 per cent renewable energy generation in 2020, while South Australia is on track to join it by 2027.

Alan Langworthy, author of the NT government's 2017 Roadmap to Renewables report, said solar power was the cheapest wholesale source of electricity in the territory.

But he said the previous NT Labor government hadn't prepared the network for it.

"It's too late," he said.

"We don't have enough time to get from where we are, to where we need to be for 2030."

Alan Langworthy is the architect of the NT government's Roadmap to Renewables report. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Mr Langworthy said he'd tried to develop a 50-megawatt solar farm at Livingstone, south of Darwin, with funding from local investors.

However, the solar farm failed to ever be connected to the grid.

"Nothing was being done on the network side to make way for new technology," he said.

Is gas from the Beetaloo Basin guaranteed?

Saul Kavonic, the head of energy research at MST Marquee, said he understood the CLP's decision to scrap the target, but it wasn't a reason to give up on renewables.

He also warned against an over-reliance on shale gas from the Beetaloo Basin as the answer to lower power prices.

The gas-rich Beetaloo sits about 500 kilometres south-east of Darwin, and has been pegged as the future of the NT's gas supply.

Gas companies have been exploring the Beetaloo Basin. (Supplied: Tamboran Resources Limited)

"If the Beetaloo is developed at commercial scale, it can provide a future source of relatively lower cost, reliable and abundant gas supply," Mr Kavonic said.

" But I think, particularly from a government perspective, you can't be putting all your eggs in one basket. "

Fracking fluid spills revealed in the NT's Beetaloo Basin Photo shows An area of dead trees and vegetation Traditional owners and a scientist fear there have been more fracking fluid spills by gas companies exploring the Northern Territory's Beetaloo Basin.

Gas companies Tamboran Resources and Empire Energy have been exploring the Beetaloo since the NT government approved a full-scale fracking industry in 2023.

Tamboran Resources expects first gas to flow in 2026, while Empire Energy expects to start delivering gas later this year.

Both have signed secretive deals to supply gas to the NT government.

However, neither company has reached a final investment decision on their fracking projects.

Central Petroleum has also agreed to supply gas from the Amadeus Basin in Central Australia.

So, where does the NT's gas come from?

The NT government-owned Power and Water Corporation (PWC) has been buying emergency gas at high prices from Santos and Inpex since 2021 due to shortfalls at Eni's Blacktip field.

PWC spent $43 million on the emergency deals in 2023-24.

Mr Kavonic said prioritising Beetaloo gas at the expense of other energy sources could risk more emergency gas deals in the future — at a massive cost to taxpayers.

"If the Beetaloo's development ends up being slower than hoped for — just like the renewables rollout — what are the contingency plans?" he asked.

Should solar still be on the table?

Greg Bourne, a former oil industry executive with BP, said the NT had a big opportunity to grow its critical minerals industry and build large solar farms.

That work is already underway by the private sector.

Tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes is pushing ahead with plans to build a 10-gigawatt solar farm spanning more than 12,000 hectares near the remote town of Elliott.

A render of the planned SunCable solar project in the Northern Territory outback. (Supplied: Sun Cable)

The SunCable project aims to transport electricity to Darwin via an 800km overhead transmission line, then on to Singapore through an underwater cable.

The project received federal environmental approval last year, and is aiming to achieve a final investment decision by 2027-28.

The NT government estimated it would cost up to $5 billion to see out the 50 per cent renewables target.

But Mr Bourne, who now works for the Climate Council, said the cost paled in comparison to the price of "increasingly intense cyclones" and bushfires caused by global warming.

"The last thing we want to do is let the gas run and let the climate rip," he said.

A spokesperson for Essential Services Minister Steve Edgington said several solar projects were making progress across the NT.

The spokesperson said Jacana Energy was working to provide rooftop solar to social housing tenants in Tennant Creek, and renewable energy to residents in Marlinja and Borroloola.

They also said PWC was progressing several solar energy projects, and Territory Generation was planning to deliver its first battery energy storage system project for Darwin and Katherine.

title: Shoplifters make life even harder for regional traders
text:
Al Taylor has managed to keep his small business afloat through the ups and downs of the COVID pandemic and cost-of-living crisis but now there is a new threat to his shop — theft.



Mr Taylor has operated a combined indoor skate centre and retail store at Wodonga, in Victoria's north-east, for almost five years, but constant shoplifting is taking a toll.

A $300 scooter was stolen from the shop floor two weeks ago.

CCTV footage captured a young male making off with it while staff were helping another customer.

"[He's taken] a look around and just rode it out the door," he said.

" Taking something of value from a business really is taking money out of someone's pocket. "

Mr Taylor, who also runs a skateboarding program for young people dealing with mental health issues, said people were resorting to theft as cost-of-living pressures worsen.

"I understand the stigma about opening up about struggling financially ... but if someone ... needed food or any items, plenty of people can help them out."

Emotional toll

The latest data from Victoria's Crime Statistics Agency shows store thefts across Victoria have almost doubled since 2022.

About 37,800 stealing offences were recorded in Victoria in 2024, up from 27,600 in 2023 and 19,700 in 2022.

In 2024, Greater Shepparton recorded 426 thefts from retail stores, compared to 170 offences the previous year.

Fleur Brown. (Supplied: Australian Retail Association)

Victoria Police says a third of all thefts from stores are related to alcohol.

Australia Retail Association chief industry affairs officer Fleur Brown said violent crime also had a profound impact on retail staff and customers and the emotional toll on shop owners and their employees was immense.

"No-one should have to go to work fearing for their safety, but sadly that is the reality for many in the retail sector," Ms Brown said.

"A 2-to-3 per cent loss of merchandise can amount to 25 per cent loss in profit," she said.

Cost-of-living having an impact

Glen Robinson, general manager of Albury Business Connect, the chamber of commerce, said retail crime was up with graffiti and vehicle crime as significant and emerging issues in the border region.

"There is no question that cost of living is having an impact on theft," Mr Robinson says.

"Around school and Christmas holidays is when you'll see a spike in theft [and]... usually it's younger members of our communities taking the opportunities."

Glen Robinson. (Supplied: Glen Robinson)

Mr Robinson said "bigger ticket" thefts of meat and fruit in supermarkets were also increasing.

"We are seeing spikes everywhere with regards to people taking things to just keep food on the table, whether it be small stuff in jacket pockets at the checkout or the more blatant snatch-and-grab where stores aren't equipped enough to chase [the thief]," he said.

title: Brisbane land valuations up 17pc, with regional increases as high as 247pc
text:
Land valuations in Brisbane have climbed almost 20 per cent, while some regional locations have seen increases of more than 230 per cent, likely leading to costlier council rates and land tax bills.

Queensland's independent valuer-general, Laura Dietrich, issued more than 790,000 valuations this week, spanning 14 council areas.

Queensland's independent valuer-general, Laura Dietrich, is responsible for calculating land valuations. (Supplied: Western Queensland Alliance of Councils)

Brisbane City Council's re-evaluation included almost 351,000 properties with a total value of $346.2 billion, an increase of 17 per cent.

The overall median value of residential land in the capital city was $720,000.

"Brisbane continues to be one of the strongest capital city housing markets, and that's mainly due to population growth and infrastructure projects that have been done since we last did the valuation in 2022," Ms Dietrich said.

"Some of those big investments are the Kangaroo Point Bridge, the Eagle Street Pier project, Queens Wharf, and the Metro Tunnel Project."

Brisbane's Kangaroo Point Bridge officially opened late last year. (Supplied: Brett Sarapung/Brisbane City Council)

Brisbane's land values were last reviewed in 2023, rising 12 per cent then, and 17 per cent the previous year.

In Logan — one of the state's biggest council areas — total land values increased 19 per cent, with residential land now at a median value of $375,000, driven by strong population growth and improved transport infrastructure.

Other notable land value increases included:

Toowoomba, up 31 per cent to a median residential land value of $265,000

Cairns, up 31 per cent to a median residential land value of $280,000

Rockhampton, up 36 per cent to a median residential land value of $134,000

Townsville, up 27 per cent to a median residential land value of $192,500

Values completed prior to extreme weather

Ms Dietrich said it was important to note the valuations reflected the market prior to October of last year, before serious flooding events and ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred.

The aftermath of ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred Photo shows A ute surrounded by floodwater with Clayton's towing in the background. Approaching slowly and hitting hard, the weather system wreaked havoc across south-east Queensland and northern NSW — with homes, businesses and beaches damaged.

"Our valuers consider a range of factors, including the damage caused to land property sales with flood-affected areas and historical flooding in the region," she said.

"Future land valuations will continue to take into consideration adverse weather and flooding."

Land valuations are used by local governments to make decisions on council rates, and the state government relies on them to calculate land tax charges.

"As the valuer-general, I have no role in council rates. Councils have many options to be able to manage their rates," Ms Dietrich said.

The state government relies on these valuations to calculate land tax charges. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

The Gold Coast, Sunshine Coast and Moreton Bay were notable exclusions to the latest valuations.

"As valuers, we don't set the market, we interpret the market," Ms Dietrich said.

"So, when I make the decision to value different LGAs each year, we go through the process of looking at market movements, talking to stakeholders and councils, and considering all the things that have taken place since the last time we did an evaluation."

Rural locations skyrocket

Several south-west Queensland councils saw massive rises in land valuations, including Paroo (247 per cent), Murweh (238 per cent), and Quilpie (236 per cent).

Some rural Queensland regions have experienced good seasons recently, which Queensland's valuer-general says has impacted land valuations. (ABC News: Elsie Adamo)

"A combination of generally good seasons, low interest rates and high commodity prices since 2020 to 2022, has seen an increase in rural land values," Ms Dietrich said.

"While we've seen interest rate rises and lower commodity prices over the last 12 months, we haven't seen the rural prices drop.

"Producers continue to take a long-term view, competing for properties that are strategically important to them.

"We haven't seen any correction to the rural market to date, and that's really because there's a low supply."

title: Tiny Huxley needs a hero. He's found one in marathon man Mitch
text:
A week before Christmas in Broken Hill, Jess and Bree Maguire's lives changed forever.

After welcoming baby Huxley on August 22, they had been through months of "traumatic" tests and round trips to Adelaide, with no answers to what was amiss with their boy.

He had struggled to latch, had issues with reflux and suffered repeated infections.

A week before December 25, Bree and Jess were called to their paediatrician in Broken Hill and told Huxley had Angelman syndrome, a rare genetic condition that affects the functioning of nerves in the brain and can cause physical and intellectual problems.

Jess says Huxley's smile lights up every room he is in. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

They had no idea what that meant and were emotionally exhausted.

Now, three months on, their close friend Mitch McKenny is gearing up to run across New South Wales, from Broken Hill to Newcastle — the equivalent of 27 marathons in 27 days — raising money for research into the condition.

'He was perfect'

Bree and Jess Maguire were elated when they found out they were expecting a baby boy.

"We were just so excited and happy," Jess said.

"In a household filled with girls [we were excited] to have a boy," Bree agreed.

The days leading up to Huxley's birth were filled with nervous anticipation, but when he arrived all nerves were pushed aside.

"He was born and he was perfect," Jess said.

Bree (left) and Huxley had to fly to Adelaide with the Royal Flying Doctor Service twice during emergencies. (Supplied)

"He struggled with some breathing but nothing too dramatic. We thought he was OK," she said.

The pair took Huxley home and it soon became clear something was wrong.

He was not feeding and he was often screaming.

The couple brought him back to Broken Hill Base Hospital, distressed that their child might be in pain.

“Over the course of their investigations, they found he had reflux of the bladder and kidney, which was causing UTIs, so he was consistently getting infections,” Jess said.

It was the first step in a four-month journey to a diagnosis that ended in their paediatrician's office in Broken Hill.

Huxley is the pair's second IVF baby after Sage, 3. Bree also has an older child, Asha, 14. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

The paediatrician explained the complex syndrome would likely mean Huxley would never walk or talk and would need constant care for the rest of his life.

Jess remembers feeling "numb".

"Our perfect little boy, here he was sitting there and it was like they took his life away from us. But he was physically right there," she said.

Hope on the horizon

When the couple got home they searched the web to understand Angelman syndrome.

One of the groups they learnt about was FAST, the Foundation for Angelman Syndrome Therapeutics Australia.

Meagan Cross is the chief executive of FAST, whose daughter, Molly, has Angelman syndrome. (Supplied: Meagan Cross)

FAST chief executive Meagan Cross's daughter Molly is 18 and has the syndrome.

"It affects a single gene and it only affects the mother's copy of it," she said.

"It causes a complex disability that affects nearly all the aspects of life — gross motor, fine motor, delays in walking and sitting."

Ms Cross said the foundation was focused on research while offering support to parents and carers of children with Angelman syndrome.

"The hole in your heart will always be there," she said.

"Something has happened to your child; sometimes it's not as raw, but sometimes it can be really raw, [but] there's a lot of hope for the future."

Professor David Armor is a clinical geneticist at Melbourne University and part of the team involved in an international trial of treatment for Angelman syndrome at Melbourne's Royal Children's Hospital.

He says the trial investigates turning on the silenced paternal copy of a gene.

"Kids with Angelman syndrome have one copy from the father, which is silenced in the body, and there are trials underway to switch on that paternal copy which, at least in theory, should be able to fulfil the same role as the maternal copy," he said.

Professor Amor says a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome is usually made between the ages of two and three years old. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

Professor Armor explained that the trial involved injections every three months.

"Using a specific treatment to activate the parental copy, it's pretty complicated and involves the child having injections into fluid around the spinal cord and the brain every three months or so," he said.

"At the moment we don't have results to this trial, so we don't know if it's going to be proved to be effective or not,".

Even so, Professor Armor said the future was looking bright.

"There's a lot more optimism now than there has been that we might be able to decrease the severity of symptoms," he said.

'I won't let that answer be nothing'

A friend of the Maguires, Mitch McKenny, remembers hearing about Huxley's diagnosis and instantly Googling.

His young son attends Jess's family daycare and he felt indebted to her.

"My young fella, my toddler, goes to daycare with Jessie and as a result of that has grown tremendously and has benefited from some outstanding care from them," he said.

"When it became clear that young Huxley was unwell, I felt [the need] to pay it forward in a sense."

Mitch will start his run on August 22, Huxley's first birthday. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

After talking to Meagan, he decided to undertake the run not just to raise money but also spread awareness of Angelman syndrome.

He hopes the campaign, named "Huxley's Heroes" will help treatments become available in Australian homes.

So far, the campaign has raised around $40,000 with local clubs and pubs, sporting groups and individuals donating.

Mr McKenny feels the more-than-1,000km run is an apt dedication to those with the disorder.

"After I got permission from my wife, I decided that it had to be a physical challenge because these kids and their mums and dads are physically challenged every day," he said.

Mr McKenny starts the run on August 22, Huxley's first birthday.

"One day, when [my son] is older he'll ask me what I did for his mate Huxley and I won't let that answer be 'nothing'," he said.

title: This brass band is offering free tuition to bring in a new generation
text:
At 85 and 11 years old respectively, John Quinn and Oliver Buckland are breathing new life into the West Tamar Municipal Band.

Note by note, scale by scale, John is teaching Oliver the fundamentals of the cornet in an attempt to revitalise the northern Tasmanian brass band's membership.

Mr Quinn, who has played the compact brass instrument since 1955, is hoping Oliver will develop the skills to join the senior band.

"He listens and he practices … he's a good boy," Mr Quinn said.

With the typical band member aged in their 70s, Oliver, who is in grade six at Exeter Primary School, belongs to a cohort of students who have put up their hands to receive tutoring from the existing players in a bid to revitalise the group.

After being wowed by classic tunes such as When the Saints and Ode to Joy over the past year, Oliver hopes "more and more people come and join, so it keeps on sounding better and we get more people to play."

Paul Laverty is the band's conductor and secretary. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

New life for old instruments

This year, the brass band celebrates its 146th birthday. It's a tradition that band president Mary Parsell wants to keep going.

"The average age of our band is creeping up, and we wanted some younger people to come and join us," she said.

" We had a lot of old instruments in the cupboard doing nothing. "

The band has recruited 14 school students who come along on a Tuesday afternoon to learn a brass instrument of their choice with a mentor.

"It costs nothing because we don't charge," Ms Parsell said.

"We give them an instrument and they have to guarantee it comes back in the same condition. We give them a folder with music, and we give them lessons for free.

"But we do feed them biscuits and a drink, so that might be half the fun."

There are 14 Exeter Primary School students learning brass instruments alongside band members. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

After a little over a year, there are now two students who are playing alongside their more experienced counterparts in the senior band.

"I hope it continues for many more years, but it relies on the goodwill of the other band members who come Tuesday afternoon and play for an hour and then stay and play with the kids," Mrs Parsell said.

"So while they're keen to teach, I think it will go on stronger and stronger."

Friendships formed through music

Zoe Williams, 12, is one of the original recruits who has gone on to play the baritone horn with the senior band.

This year, she's been paired with 73-year-old Exeter resident Richard Tite as she continues to master what he describes as a "harmonious instrument" that generates a "beautiful, mellow sound in the middle of a band".

For Zoe, her mentor's enthusiasm for the lesser-known horn has been infectious.

"I absolutely love him," she said.

Zoe Williams (centre) now plays the baritone horn with the senior band, and is mentored by Richard Tite (right). (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

"He's also quite a character as well, very funny … I think he's kind of rubbed off on me a bit … it's great to have him around.

"I love that I get to bond with all these people … my parents call me an older lady."

For Mr Tite, it's been a two-way learning experience.

Program bringing together young and old Photo shows An old woman in pink shirt and cream cardigan sits in between two high school students in school uniform An Adelaide program bringing together the old and young has helped participants form unlikely connections.

"She's a very enjoyable character," he said.

"If she's not happy with what she's doing, she'll tell me … and she'll also tell the bandmaster if I'm doing something wrong, which is lovely."

He's hoping that players such as Zoe will extend the brass band's future.

"We need the next generation coming through."

Zoe Williams says she enjoys bonding with other band members. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

Teaching new tricks at 90

Like his younger band members, 90-year-old cornet player Doug Sawyer is also relatively new to his chosen instrument.

"I was almost 80 when I first started," he said.

"I heard a talk on the wireless one time and the fella was saying if you want to keep young and keep your brain active … grab an instrument and learn to read music.

"So that's what I did and it's been really good."

Describing the process as similar to learning another language, Mr Sawyer went through music book after music book to slowly grasp the basics.

Doug Sawyer, 90, took up the cornet about 10 years ago. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

After moving to Tasmania only a few years ago from Western Australia, Mr Sawyer is delighted he is now able to share this passion with his peers and a new cohort of musicians.

"They have a real job to get any sort of noise," he said.

" But … when they get going and play the notes, it's really fantastic to listen to it and see the achievement and the look on their face when they can play a tune. "

title: Expat lands record number of US scholarships for Aussie basketballers
text:
There's a thick mid-west American twang to the commentators' voice as he calls out over the loudspeaker: "Aussie! Aussie! Aussie!"

The basketball stadium full of Montana college students dutifully responds: "Oi! Oi! Oi!"

The chant repeats every time Justin Asi shoots a basket for the Dawson Community College Buccaneers, which happens regularly.

He's half a world away from his old home court in Dandenong, an outer suburb in Melbourne's south-east.

Australian Justin Asi shoots for the Dawson Community College Buccaneers. (Supplied: Dawson Community College)

While the Australian indoor sports centre doesn't have the stands of cheering fans, it is still full — of other young hopefuls, wanting to follow in Justin Asi's footsteps and secure a scholarship to play in the US.

"Low! Get lower!" the coach yells to the Melbourne teens lined up in drill formation bouncing balls between their legs.

He walks among the boys, offering specific advice and corrections, but he's clearly concerned some aren't giving it their all and brings them in for a chat.

Members of the Red Roo program aspire to be among the growing number of Aussie basketballers breaking into the US. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

"Just because something is easy, does that mean you don't try when you do it?" he asks.

"If you're going to be cruising through practise the whole time, it's only going to affect you, it's not going to affect me."

Expectations are high in the Red Roo program which helps aspiring basketballers secure sporting scholarships to the US. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

The pace is quick — and the expectations are high — at Red Roo Sports.

Watching on and helping with the coaching as needed is 19-year-old Kuriowl Chol, known as KC.

He's among the latest players to secure a scholarship and will be flying to the US in a couple of months.

Kuriowl Chol is preparing to head to the US on a basketball scholarship. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

Growing number of Aussies securing US scholarships

The number of young Australians going to study in America on sporting scholarships is increasing "year on year", according to the Australian Institute of Sport.

There are different organisations that govern college sports, the biggest is the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA).

After a dip during COVID-19, figures up to 2023 show the Australian interest is rebounding.

Elizabeth Thompson from the NCAA says student numbers from Australia are now at an "all-time high".

"Australia in particular is one that continues to grow and move its way to the top of the charts," she says.

Australia provides the fifth highest number of international student athletes competing in the NCAA.

There are a variety of pathways young Australians are taking to get a sports scholarship, but Ms Thompson says social media has been a game changer.

"The coaches use social media just as much as the student athletes do, and I think that lends to the increasing number of student athletes that you see on rosters."

There has been a notable jump in Australians joining the gridiron ranks, in particular as punters, and women's basketball has also been surging.

While the US pathway is clearly a popular choice, it's not the only one.

Australian basketballer Jade Melbourne shunned the US collegiate system, before going on to play in the WNBA and the Olympics.

Twenty-five scholarships in one year

On the court in Dandenong, one of the young players, Jamaal Duhovic, has a simple answer when asked what he wants to get out of Red Roo.

"In the future, I'd really like to go to America, get a scholarship, and play," he says.

He says seeing older teammates, like KC, succeed is "inspiring".

"I really look up to KC, and in the future, I hope I can be as good — or maybe even better than KC," he says while glancing in the direction of the more than 2-metres-tall KC and grinning.

Jamaal Duhovic hopes to secure a US scholarship in the future. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

KC will be moving to Montana in June, to pull on a singlet for Dawson Community College, replacing former Red Roo players Justin Asi and Kur Maler.

After completing their two years of junior college, both Asi and Maler are going through a recruiting process to hopefully get a spot in an NCAA school.

"It was just a thought, a dream, but I never thought I'd actually do it," KC explains.

"It was really challenging, but I took on the challenge and I got it done."

He is one of 25 Red Roo players to receive US scholarships last year, in a record year for the club.

Moving to the US to play basketball is a dream come true for Kuriowl Chol. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

It was established by an American expat, he says as a way giving back to the community.

"Our formula is quite simple, it's excellence over time, with discipline, equals success," James Kerr explains.

"If you can maintain that excellence over time, there's a good chance you can advance in life."

James Kerr (left) set up the Red Roo program to give talented basketballers opportunities to progress in the sport. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

The program is designed to offer a different way to higher levels of the sport, particularly for young people who may not fit the usual representative pathways.

The Red Roo players compete in competitions and showcases that are watched online by scouts in America.

The first players who went to the United States have since returned and some are working with the next generation, coaching at Red Roo.

Mr Kerr is now also running AAU, the Amateur Athletic Union — Australia, one of several agencies promoting US sporting scholarships.

"With AAU and a national presence, we think that we can do 100 (scholarships) this year," he says.

James Kerr's Red Roo program secured a record number of basketball scholarships last year. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

'Brings the community together'

While some may aspire to a future as a professional athlete, for many of the young Red Roo players the opportunity to study and have new experiences is just as motivating.

KC says while he is looking forward to playing, he is also excited to earn his degree and "further (his) education".

Year 11 student Chibuikem Anyadoro is also eyeing a scholarship, perhaps to an ivy league school.

"I think it's really important to emphasise the student in student athlete," he explains.

"I believe it's really important not just to have the basketball side of things, but also the academic side of things — it's a link, you can't have one without the other."

Chibuikem Anyadoro (white singlet under the hoop) blocks a shot by his Red Roo teammate. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

Aside from its US exports, the Red Roo program is having broader benefits in the community, according to one former player.

"It brings community together, a lot of us young people like to be together and so when we're around one another and we get to do it in a positive environment, we excel," Mamuch Chol says.

Mamuch Chol hopes the Red Roo program can provide mentors for the South Sudanese community. (ABC News: Natalie Whiting)

He now runs an NGO called NextGen Unite, which works with the local South Sudanese community and says it is looking to partner with Red Roo.

"Red Roo is already doing pathways at the moment, but we'd like to expand some of its programs around mentoring.

"We'd also like to be able to find ways for young people to be able to find employment."

As the program keeps expanding, so too are the goals.

title: Pilot critical but stable after crash at Avalon International Airshow
text:
A pilot involved in a crash at the Avalon International Airshow in Victoria on Friday remains in a critical but stable condition in hospital.

The pilot, Glenn Collins from Paul Bennet Airshows, based in Hunter in NSW, crashed the aircraft while conducting a demonstration about 5:15pm on Friday.

Mr Collins was the sole occupant of the plane, known as a Pitts Special aerobatic aircraft.

According to a biography on the Paul Bennet Airshows website, Mr Collins is an seasoned pilot with more than 2,700 hours flying experience.

Pilot Glenn Collins suffered critical injuries in the crash at the Avalon International Airshow on Friday. (Supplied: Paul Bennet Airshows)

Paul Bennet Airshows said Mr Collins was "one of our long-time Sky Aces pilots."

"The pilot is in a serious but stable condition and has been transferred to hospital for treatment," Paul Bennet Airshows said in a statement.

"Our thoughts are with his family and we are grateful for the emergency services who responded quickly.

"Our team and families appreciate the well-wishes and support."

The plane that crashed was one of four aircraft involved in an aerobatic display at the airshow when the accident occurred.

The crash happened at about 5:15pm on Friday at the Avalon airshow. (AFP: Paul Crock)

Crash witnessed by hundreds of spectators

Shaun Lenehan was in the crowd at the airshow when the crash happened a few hundred metres in front of spectators.

"Everyone stopped straight away and they rolled the fire trucks out and they kind of put a pause on everything straight away," he said.

"It looked like it could have been a fatal crash by the way it had hit the ground and disintegrated. He was pulling out of a dive so he was going quite fast."

The aircraft was one of four planes involved in an aerobatic display from Paul Bennet Airshows. (AAP Image: Michael Currie)

Another spectator, Andrew Pearce, said the plane hit the ground as it was coming out of a loop.

"He didn't just nosedive, like he kind of hit his belly," he said.

"The cockpit was intact where he was but the wings were, like I don't know if they were detached from the plane, but they were like crumpled in front of the plane."

Safety bureau says investigation will take months

The chief commissioner of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB), Angus Mitchell, said investigators had almost finished examining the crash site and would now continue their investigation of the plane wreckage in a hangar.

He said investigators would look into what pilots were tasked to do for the flight display, the approvals processes leading up to it, the plane's maintenance history and the pilot's history.

A number of recording devices have been recovered from the plane as well as mobile phone footage from the public.

ATSB chief commissioner Angus Mitchell says it's too early to say what caused the plane crash. (ABC News)

"That is all very important for us in recreating what's occurred here," Mr Mitchell told reporters on Saturday.

"I suspect it will be a number of months before we have anything to say regarding what occurred yesterday and, most importantly, is there anything else that we can work with in the industry to make sure that occurrences like this are lessened."

He encouraged anyone else with footage of the crash to submit it to the ATSB.

Airshow to continue on Saturday

Avalon Australian International Airshow CEO Justin Giddings confirmed the pilot was the only person hurt in the incident.

"The incident occurred well away from the crowds in attendance and no member of the public was injured," he said.

"The Avalon Australian International Airshow concluded the day's activities to allow the Australian Transport Safety Bureau investigation team to have full and free access to the site.

" Our thoughts are with the pilot and his family, friends and team members. "

The airshow is resuming on Saturday after being suspended following Friday's crash. (ABC News)

The airshow is proceeding on Saturday, with gates opening at 8am, although the start of the flying display will be delayed.

Mr Giddings said airshow attendees who were forced to leave early on Friday because of the crash would be offered general admission tickets for Sunday.

title: ‘Naysayers’: Queen claims victory over online reading club with 12 million members
text:
London: Queen Camilla has claimed victory over the many “naysayers” who did not believe her online book club would be a success.

As she marked the fourth anniversary of The Queen’s Reading Room at a star-studded reception at Clarence House this week, Camilla revealed that she had built a “family” of 12 million readers spanning 173 countries.

She said her aim was simply to “make life better”.

Queen Camilla speaks as King Charles looks on during a reception to mark the launch of the Queen’s reading room medal at Clarence House on Tuesday. Credit: Getty Images

The Queen was supported by her family, with King Charles, her sister Annabel Elliot, and children Tom Parker Bowles and Laura Lopes mingling with a host of authors and literary figures.

title: ‘My new homeland’: Russian-born tennis star Daria Kasatkina switches allegiance to Australia
text:
Russian-born tennis star Daria Kasatkina is switching allegiances to Australia after her application for permanent residency was accepted by the federal government.

The world No.12 has been playing on the tour as a neutral athlete after Russian and Belarusian players were banned from competing under their own flags following Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

Daria Kasatkina, pictured playing at the Australian Open in January, will compete for Australia now that she has been granted permanent residency. Credit: Getty Images

In an Instagram post, Kasatkina expressed her joy in gaining permanent residency in Australia.

“I am delighted to let you all know that my application for permanent residency has been accepted by the Australian Government,” she wrote.
